explanation: Vowels are long before a single consonant or when doubled (aa, ee, oo) or followed by 'h'. They are short before two or more consonants.
Umlauts change the vowel sound. 'ä' is like 'e' in 'bed' [ɛ]. 'ö' and 'ü' have no English equivalent; they are fronted versions of 'o' and 'u' made with rounded lips.
'ie' is a long 'ee' sound [iː]. 'ei', 'ai', 'ey' are all 'eye' [aɪ]. 'eu' and 'äu' are both 'oy' [ɔʏ].
In most native German words, 'v' is pronounced like 'f' [f]. In loanwords, it is often pronounced like 'v' [v].
Voiced consonants like 'b', 'd', and 'g' at the end of a word become voiceless, sounding like 'p', 't', and 'k' respectively.
After front vowels (i, e, ä, ö, ü) 'ch' is a soft, hissing [ç]. After back vowels (a, o, u) it is a hard, throaty [x] sound.
At the start of a word or between vowels, 's' is voiced like 'z' in 'zoo' [z]. When it's 'ss', 'ß', or at the end of a word, it's voiceless like 's' in 'see' [s].
'sch' is always 'sh' [ʃ]. At the start of a word or syllable, 'sp' and 'st' are pronounced 'shp' [ʃp] and 'sht' [ʃt].
The letter 'z' is always pronounced as 'ts' [ts], like the end of 'cats'.
A combination sound [pf] where you start to say 'p' but release it as an 'f'.
The German 'r' can be pronounced in several ways. A common pronunciation is a 'gargled' sound at the back of the throat [ʁ] (uvular fricative).
At the end of a word, the suffix '-ig' is pronounced like the 'soft ch' (Ich-laut), as if it were '-ich' [ɪç].
This combination is pronounced like 'j' in English 'jam' [dʒ], and is mainly used for loanwords.
